case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Central Calcutta v. the assessee Company

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 268 of 1964 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 268 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 29, 1962 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 18 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 29, 1962 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 1.8 of 1955.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal referred questions to Calcutta High Court under s. 19 of the Business Profits Tax Act 1947 at instance of Commissioner of Income-tax Central Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner of Income-tax  Central  Calcutta, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal referred the following questions for the opinion of the High Court

facts.text: High Court answered all three questions in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court recorded answers in the affirmative on all the questions. The Commissioner of Income-tax has appealed to this Court with special leave.

facts.text: Assessee company is non-resident, incorporated in Delaware, United States of America.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee Company is a number-resident. It was incorporated in the State of Delaware in the United States of America with the object of taking over the assets

facts.text: Assessee company took over assets of Socony Vacuum Oil Company and Standard Oil Company New Jersey.

anchor.surface_text: with the object of taking over the assets of two companypanies- Socony Vacuum Oil Company and Standard Oil Company  New Jersey .

facts.text: Capital of assessee company was 10,000,000 divided into 100,000 shares of 100 each.

anchor.surface_text: The capital of the assessee companypany was 10,000,000 divided into 100,000 shares of the value of 100 each.

facts.text: Book value of assets of Socony Vacuum Oil Company: 97,715,701.

anchor.surface_text: On the date of acquisition the book values of the assets of the two companypanies as recorded in their books of account were Socony Vacuum Oil Company 97,715,701

facts.text: Book value of assets of Standard Oil Company New Jersey: 46,767,397.

anchor.surface_text: Standard Oil Company  New Jersey  46,767,397 In companysideration of transfer of these assets, the assessee companypany allotted to each companypany 49,995 shares

facts.text: Assessee allotted 49,995 shares to each transferor company and serial bonds of 13,093,000 to Socony Vacuum Oil Company.

anchor.surface_text: In companysideration of transfer of these assets, the assessee companypany allotted to each companypany 49,995 shares and to Socony Vacuum Oil Company serial bonds of the value of 13,093,000.

facts.text: Remaining ten shares divided equally between two transferor companies for cash at par value.

anchor.surface_text: The remaining ten shares were divided equally between the two transferor companypanies for cash at par value.

facts.text: Excess of net value of assets transferred over par value of stock and serial bonds entered as Capital paid in Surplus.

anchor.surface_text: The excess of the net value of the assets so transferred over the par value of the stock issued and the serial bonds was entered in the books in an account styled Capital paid in Surplus.

facts.text: Capital paid in Surplus account reduced to 117,561,317 and stood unchanged during relevant three years.

anchor.surface_text: By adjustment entries the Capital paid in Surplus account was reduced to 117,561,317 and throughout the period of three years to which these appeals relate, in the balance sheets

facts.text: Serial bonds issued to Socony Vacuum Oil Company were later redeemed.

anchor.surface_text: The serial bonds issued to the Socony Vacuum Oil Company were later redeemed.

facts.text: Net profits earned by company shown under Earned Surplus or Earnings reinvested.

anchor.surface_text: The net profits earned by the Company year after year, subject to certain appropriations were shown in the balance sheet under the caption Earned Surplus or Earnings reinvested.

facts.text: Earned Surplus at end of 1945: 29,557,597.

anchor.surface_text: At the end of 1945, the balance of Earned Surplus was 29,557,597 and by the end of 1948 the account stood at 73,766,592.

facts.text: Earned Surplus at end of 1948: 73,766,592.

anchor.surface_text: At the end of 1945, the balance of Earned Surplus was 29,557,597 and by the end of 1948 the account stood at 73,766,592.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer disallowed inclusion of Capital paid in Surplus and Earned Surplus in computation of taxable capital under Sch. II r. 2(1).

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim of the assessee Company for inclusion of the accounts Capital paid in Surplus and Earned Surplus in the companyputation of taxable capital

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed with Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: under Sch. II r. 2 1  of the Business Profits Tax Act and the Appellate 37 1 Assistant Commissioner agreed with him.

facts.text: Tribunal held Capital paid in Surplus is premium per r.3 Sch.II or reserve per r.2(1), and Earned Surplus is reserve.

anchor.surface_text: But the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held that the difference between the value of the assets taken over and the value of stock and serial bonds issued by the assessee Company was premium

facts.text: High Court agreed with Tribunal on the three questions in reference under s.19 Business Profits Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: In a reference under S. 19 of the Business Profits Tax Act, the High Court agreed with the view of the Tribunal on the three questions referred for its opinion.

facts.text: Tribunal found amount in Capital paid in Surplus retained in business.

anchor.surface_text: It was found by the Tribunal that the amount entered in the balance sheet as Capital paid in Surplus was retained in the business of the assessee companypany

facts.text: Earned Surplus balances: 1945:29M odd, 1946:43M odd, 1947:56M odd, 1948:73M odd.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that the sum of 29,000,000 odd, 43,000,000 odd, 56,000,000 odd and 73,000,000 odd for the respective years

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore right in holding that the difference between the book value of the assets transferred and the par value of capital stock issued was premium.

issues.text: Whether on the facts found the Tribunal was right in holding that the sum of 117,000,000 appearing in the Balance Sheet of the assessee Company under the head Capital paid in Surplus and constituting the excess of the book value of the assets over the face value of the shares represented premium realised from the issue of the shares as contemplated by Rule 3 of Schedule II of the Business Profits Tax Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts found the Tribunal was right in holding that the sum of 117,000,000 appearing in the Balance Sheet of the assessee Company under the head Capital paid in Surplus and constituting the excess of the book value of the assets over the face value of the shares represented premium realised

issues.text: Whether on facts and in the circumstances of the case the Tribunal was right in holding that the fact that the amount in question had been built up out of capital and not out of taxed profits would not prevent it from being reserve as contemplated by Sub-Rule 1 of Rule 2 of the Schedule II of the Business Profits Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on facts and in the circumstances of the case the Tribunal was right in holding that the fact that the amount in question had been built up out of capital and not out of taxed profits would not prevent it from being reserve as contemplated by Sub- Rule 1 of Rule 2 of the Schedule 11 of the Business Profits Tax Act.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that the sum of 29,000,000 odd, 43,000,000 odd, 56,000,000 odd and 73,000,000 odd for the respective years appearing in the Balance Sheets of the assessee as Earned Surplus would be treated as a reserve within the meaning of Sub-Rule 1 of Rule 2 of the Schedule II of the Business Profits Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that the sum of 29,000,000 odd, 43,000,000 odd, 56,000,000 odd and 73,000,000 odd for the respective years appearing in the Balance Sheets of the assessee as, Earned Surplus would be treated as a reserve within the meaning of Sub-Rule 1 of Rule 2 of the Schedule 11 of the Business Profits Tax Act.

issues.text: Whether the Capital paid in Surplus represents reserves not allowed in computing the profits of the company for the purposes of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 within the meaning of Rule 2(1) of Schedule II of the Business Profits Tax Act even if not premium under Rule 3.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee company said that even if this amount of capital paid in Surplus be not regarded as premium within the meaning of r. 3, it is still reserves within the meaning of r. 2(1). This plea found favour with the High Court.

issues.text: Whether reserves contemplated by Rule 2(1) of Schedule II must be built out of profits processed for taxation under the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Revenue raised two contentions against acceptance of that view of the High Court (1) that reserves contemplated by r. 2(1) are only those which are built out of profits processed for the purpose of taxation under the Indian Income-tax Act

issues.text: Whether the Explanation to Rule 2 of Schedule II applies to exclude the Capital paid in Surplus as a reserve created by revaluation or increasing book assets.

anchor.surface_text: and (2) that where a reserve is brought into existence by creating or increasing, by revaluation or otherwise a book asset, it cannot be included in the computation of capital by virtue of Explanation to r. 2.

issues.text: Whether Earned Surplus under the US accounting system constitutes a reserve within the meaning of Sub-Rule 1 of Rule 2 of Schedule II.

arguments.claim: Capital paid in Surplus and Earned Surplus should not be included in the computation of taxable capital under Sch. II r. 2(1) of the Business Profits Tax Act

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim of the assessee Company for inclusion of the accounts Capital paid in Surplus and Earned Surplus in the computation of taxable capital under Sch. II r. 2 1  of the Business Profits Tax Act

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court upheld Tribunal and High Court view that they qualify as premium or reserves

arguments.claim: Excess value of assets transferred over par value of shares is premium under r.3 Sch.II

anchor.surface_text: Where the value of assets transferred exceeds the par value, the difference may appropriately be regarded as premium according to the nomenclature used in India.

arguments.claim: Earned Surplus under US accounting is a general reserve under r.2(1) Sch.II as specifically allocated for business use

anchor.surface_text: In its ordinary meaning the expression reserve means something specifically kept apart for future use or for a specific occasion.

arguments.claim: Explanation to r.2 does not apply to real assets received, only book assets

anchor.surface_text: The Explanation to r. 2 has no relevance in the present case. The difference between the assets received by the company and the par value of the shares issued cannot be called a book asset

arguments.claim: Century Spinning case distinguished because Indian accounting vs US self-contained yearly accounts

holdings.text: The difference between the book value of the assets transferred and the par value of capital stock issued was premium realised from the issue of shares as contemplated by Rule 3 of Schedule II of the Business Profits Tax Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore right in holding that the difference between the book value of the assets transferred and the par value of capital stock issued was premium.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Shares issued for assets exceeding par value treated as issued at premium under company law and r.3 Sch.II; retained in business; no restriction in Delaware law; uniform treatment not required.

holdings.text: The account Capital paid in Surplus represents premium realised from the issue of shares within r.3 Sch.II or, in the alternative, reserves not allowed in computing profits under Indian IT Act within r.2(1) Sch.II.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore right in holding that the account Capital Surplus brought in the balance sheet represents premium realised from the issue of its shares within the meaning of r. 3, or in the alternative represents reserves

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alternative basis: even if not premium, qualifies as reserve; rejects revenue arguments on source of profits and Explanation applicability.

holdings.text: Capital paid in Surplus qualifies as reserve under r.2(1) Sch.II even though built out of capital not taxed profits.
holdings.reasoning_summary: r.2(1) silent on source; Explanation implies inclusion of non-profit reserves; distinguishes Century Spg. observations as obiter.

holdings.text: Explanation to r.2 Sch.II does not apply to exclude Capital paid in Surplus as it arises from real tangible assets received, not creation or revaluation of book assets.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes book assets from real assets transferred; only accountancy allocation, not revaluation.

holdings.text: Earned Surplus appearing in balance sheets constitutes reserves within meaning of sub-r.1 r.2 Sch.II of Business Profits Tax Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Under US accounting, self-contained yearly accounts allocate net profits post-appropriations to Earned Surplus as specific fund for business use, akin to general reserve; table shows retention and use; distinguishes Indian Century case.

holdings.text: Reserves under r.2(1) Sch.II need not be built exclusively out of profits processed for taxation under Indian Income-tax Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Text does not require taxed profits source; Century Spg. did not decide this; Explanation contemplates non-profit reserves.
